abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory, and
            sustainability is likely. Although it is early for the
            reform measures to show results, performance indicators
            reveal health services' compliance has increased, and,
            similarly, health referral, and/or diagnosis related
            centers, show increased productivity. The lessons spell out
            the benefits of useful preparatory technical assistance,
            drawn from the preceding Technical Assistance Health Reform
            Project (TAHRP), which paved the way to a national
            commitment to reform. However, several implementation
            problems could have been avoided, had its pilot testing
            mechanisms been used more extensively. Furthermore, given
            the fact that implementation of reform programs take longer
            than expected, financing a well phased program through
            follow-up projects, such as an Adaptable Program Lending,
            could produce better results, for it would take into account
            the lessons from the preceding operations. While
            decentralization implies competition, it would be useful to
            enhance competitiveness among entities through the provision
            of technical assistance, in order to compensate those
            institutionally weaker; for, although the project included a
            training component, a competitive training fund, as included
            in the TAHRP, would have produced better results. It is
            further suggested that the Bank's operational
            efficiency be extensively re-enforced.
